title: Everton ease pressure on Marco Silva with Watford victory in Carabao Cup
text:

Mason Holgate chose the perfect moment to score his first Everton goal, as his powerful header warmed a frigid evening.

The defender hauled a shocking contest - which waited until just before half-time for the first, lame, shot on target - out of the deep freeze, and his side into the quarter-final of the Carabao Cup.

And when Richardson confirmed victory deep into stoppage time, with a cool finish on the break, it was no more than a poor Watford side deserved.

Their apparent tactic of playing for penalties with a blanket defence was undone, when the arrival of Theo Walcott after the break roused the home side to a much improved second half.

(Image: PA)

It certainly could not have been worse after an insipid first period notable only for the commitment of Watford to sucking all life from the contest, straight from a Harry Potter novel, but half neon.

Walcott was introduced early in place of Moise Kean. The Italian hooked at half time in a substitution surely done not in anger by boss Marco Silva, but in sympathy.

Everton fans have clamoured to see more of Kean, but here we saw why he has been eased in gently.

Combined, he and Alex Iwobi cost the Mersey club £60m in the summer, but that is as far as their combination has gone so far.

(Image: Getty Images)

Here, they were on such different wavelengths there weren’t enough megahertz to cover the distance between them.

The home side were so lethargic, before the break, it even briefly encouraged Watford to conjure a chance of their own after 56 minutes when Andre Gray fired ferociously at Jordan Pickford.

In fact, the visitors should have been ahead by then, with Domingos Quina missing an easy chance when he shot wildly wide from a glorious position with time and space in front of goal.

The introduction of Walcott - how strange that he has gone from Goodison villain to hero in the space of a week - did inject some belief into the Blues, with a curling Andre Gomes left foot shot denied only by Adrian Mariappa on the line.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

Then Dominic Calvert-Lewin nodded cleverly down to Iwobi, whose sliced shot drifted onto the crossbar. Lucas Digne suffered the same fate soon after, when his deflected free kick also crashed against the woodwork.

Inevitably, it was Walcott who made the difference, his fine cross from the left, as Watford failed to clear a corner, was met with the force of a man who’d had enough, as Holgate rammed his ferocious header home.

Richarlison confirmed the victory when he raced from the half way line, as Watford finally pressed. And the over-riding emotion? Relief.
description: EVERTON 2-0 WATFORD: Mason Holgate and Richarlison scored to send the Toffees into the last eight
